mentions.context: SIFT also makes mistakes, but they are explicable: vowels stay classified as phonemes that do not involve complete obstruction of the airway (the measure looks out for the presence or absence of contact), possibly not paying enough attention to the extent of how close the articulators are supposed to come to each other (e.g. both /u/ and /o/ are back rounded vowels, and the difference between them is that /u/ is close and /o/ is close-mid; /w/ is a labial approximant, the closest consonantal equivalent of /u/).
SIFT is a feature detection algorithm.
(2) SIFT (x, y) = |matches(x, y) : match.dist

Out of all metrics, SIFT used most of its domain of values and gave the most interpretable results.

However, overall distributions SIFT A (/static p h/, x) and SIFT B (/static p h/, x) do differ (Table 1, images of A being more similar to static images than those of B; the difference is statistically significant: Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic 0.346277, p-value 0.0, and Mann-Whitney statistic 351926033.0,

Figure 4 shows the temporal evolution of SIFT of the static /f(i), f(E), f(a), f(o), f(u), f(y), f(ø)/) over the dynamic sequence /fi, fe, fE, fa, fOK, fo, fu, fy, fø, foeK, fã, fÕ, fẼ/ by A. The plots show an increment at /f/ and go down at the vowel and pause.
Contrary to EMD and SSIM, the shape of distribution of SIFT proves to not be extremely sensitive to the change of speakers.
The text of the transcription was subsequently treated by eLite HTS tool [14] to retrieve phonetic labels, and those were force aligned with HTK [22], using Merlin as frontend [21].

However, overall distributions SIFT A (/static p h/, x) and SIFT B (/static p h/, x) do differ (Table 1, images of A being more similar to static images than those of B; the difference is statistically significant: Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic 0.346277, p-value 0.0, and Mann-Whitney statistic 351926033.0,

While being reasonably good for fricatives and approximants, SIFT has a greater trouble with stops and liquids: the confusions involve not achieving the required constric-tion (as in the dynamic /S/ being the closest to the static /l(i),l(E),l(a)/) or mishandling nasalization (/b/ as the closest to the static /m(a),m(E)/).
To quantify the similarity, we use structural similarity, Wasserstein distance, and SIFT measure.
The text of the transcription was subsequently treated by eLite HTS tool [14] to retrieve phonetic labels, and those were force aligned with HTK [22], using Merlin as frontend [21].

EMD SSIM SIFT /a/ /z,i/-/oe,N/ /g,oe/-/ø,Z/ /Õ,õe/-/l,Õ/ /i/ /z,n/-/oe,N/ /g,i/-/ø,N/ /S,y/-sil,/i/ /u/ /z,N/-/oe,s/ /g,oe-/ø,Z/ /w,o/-/u,w/ Furthermore, SIFT can treat consonants, which require a higher degree of precision.

Table 1 shows the mean and standard deviation of each metric across the entire volume of speech by speakers A and B. Overall there is no linear relationship between the metrics: correlation r(SIFT, EMD) = -0.009

Then three metrics known to perform well in image processing and computer vision feature extraction were used: structural similarity (SSIM) [20], Earth mover's distance (EMD) [15] (Wasserstein distance on the histograms of the images), and scaleinvariant feature transform (SIFT) [7]. Figure 2 shows the behavior of these metrics on one of the recordings.

Static images that depict the same consonant, but in different vocalic context may produce the same distribution within the same speaker, though it may not always be the case (/r(y)/ and /r(i)/ of A, /r(i)/ and /r(E)/ and /r(y)/ and /r(o)/ of B producing same distributions in EMD and SIFT, though different in SSIM).

The distance between the static image /f(i)/ and all the dynamic images in one of the oneminute long sequences by speaker A, aligned with the power spectrum of the recording (lowermost): 1) Earth mover's distance (values from 0 to 1, the lower, the more similar); 2) structural similarity (from -1 to 1, the greater, the more similar); 3) SIFT (from 0 to 1, the greater, the more similar).
